content.raw: For whoever picks this PR up next: currently, errors in individual jobs in the batch get reported in output/e but do not result in a non-zero exit status for the batch job as a whole. That is, any train job issues are only noticed on a high level when Segway attempts to run the bundle job \(and errors out\). Instead, subjob errors should result in a nonzero exit status for the batch job.

pull_request.title: Modify Segway's scheduling to allow for 'batch' job submission in training

update.description:
#### Introduction

This pull request modifies Segway’s scheduling to allow for jobs to be submitted in ‘batches’ \(defined hereon as ‘a large script containing the segway-task commands of one or more smaller jobs’\) in a minimally invasive way for training jobs \(non-bundle\).

#### Why

Depending on the data, Segway’s EM train jobs can often run very quickly \(< 10 seconds\). In these cases, a lot of the walltime is overhead from scheduling, which is highly undesirable. In addition, cluster systems often have strict rules about running many small jobs that would prevent some users from running Segway. The addition of an option for ‘batch’ scheduling should hopefully eliminate many of these issues.

#### How to use

To enable this behavior, the user must specify `--jobs-per-batch` to be greater than 1. If `--jobs-per-batch=1` then we recover default, unbatched behavior \(each segway-wrapper command \(aka 'subjob'\) is its own cluster job/script\).

#### Code changes

The primary changes are in `queue_train_parallel`. Here, I compute the expected number of batches \(given `--jobs-per-batch`\) and distribute the train windows in the current round into batches of maximum size `--jobs-per-batch`. In each batch, each subjob writes its segway-task command to a separate job script \(as usual\). After we write the job script of the final subjob in the batch, I accumulate all the subjob scripts into one large batch script file at once, after which the batch script is submitted as a job as usual.

#### Possible issues

Things that would be good to sanity check in case I’ve made a mistake somewhere:

* Since `queue_task` is reused by other functions \(such as viterbi\), we should be careful it retains the old behavior for these other functions.
* I’ve checked that the logic for the unbatched case is effectively the same as previous behavior, but this should be verified by someone else as well.

Some things I don’t know how to fix:

* There doesn't seem to be a good way to check if the current job is a bundle job without checking if `subjob_index=None`.
* My method of checking if we expect batched or unbatched behavior is not super elegant \(checking if jobs per batch!=1, subjob\_index is not None, etc\).

@{557058:c80ca578-03a1-4ac6-b3ee-50372a3fceee} I have tried this PR locally using simpleseg \(with various split-seq and jobs-per-batch options specified\). After a first pass/sanity check, I will try it on the cluster. Thanks!

content.raw:
1. Even if each batch script is unique to it’s instance, the submitted job will be on a different host potentially reading from the file. The issue is not a write-write race condition but a write-read race condition that is exacerbated by the fact that there is a bunch of append operations taking place which may or may not sync by the same time another machine is reading from it.
2. So yes it’s a typical syncing on NFS issue. However if you just do a single write \(with all jobs\) it is much preferred since either you get all or nothing on another host anyway.

Generally if this all takes place on the same host it should not be a big issue I’d imagine since NFS typically caches the writes out to files like crazy but then you’d have to do all this weird job management inside segway-task. I’m not sure what the best quick approach to this is. Perhaps partitioning jobs inside the RestartableJobDict when things are queued in and only writing out the would-be job when the limit for a partition is hit?

@{557058:a9657985-692c-405c-995b-4e41cda7ba2b}  might have some insight on this issue.

  2. So yes it’s a typical syncing on NFS issue. However if you just do a single write (with all jobs) it is much preferred since either you get all or nothing on another host anyway.

content.raw: Aren’t those separate issues? 1\) NFS doesn’t support O\_APPEND natively, so one cannot append to the same file with multiple processes at once. But each batch script is unique to its instance, so there will only be one process writing to it at a time? 2\) Is this not the typical NFS issue where the file write might not be synced immediately?

content.raw:
This is not supported on Network File Systems \(NFS\) and _might_ cause issues. From the “open” man page:

‘O\_APPEND may lead to corrupted files on NFS file systems if more than one process appends data to a file at once.  This is because NFS does not support appending to a file, so the client kernel has to simulate it, which can't be done without a race condition.’

The potential issue is by the time the append is ‘simulated’ there could be an issue where the script is read before the final append actually takes place on NFS. This would potentially be awfully subtle since it means omitting the occasional EM job before each bundle.
